p: With decolonization, in 1960, hunting law enforcement degraded even further, modern firearms became more available, and bushmeat became increasingly commercialized, accelerating the collapse of the chimpanzee and gorilla populations (worldwide, chimpanzees were between one and two million in 1960, and had declined to 170,000–300,000 in 2003 [ 77, 78, 79]). We can tentatively suggest that ape hunting was less intense in the period 1930–1960, when the relevant protective laws were being partly enforced, than either before or after that.
